mn132:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn132:2.1: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night.
mn132:2.2: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, where he sat on the seat spread out,
mn132:2.4: “Who was inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night?”
mn132:2.6: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
mn132:2.7: “But in what way were you inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night?”
mn132:3.1: “I was doing so in this way, sir,” replied Ānanda.
mn132:3.7: are clearly seen in every case.
mn132:3.10: Today’s the day to keenly work—
mn132:3.11: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!
mn132:3.12: For there is no bargain to be struck
mn132:3.13: with Death and his mighty hordes.
mn132:3.14: The peaceful sage explained it’s those
mn132:3.17: who truly have that one fine night.”
mn132:4.1: (Ānanda went on to repeat the analysis as in the previous discourse, MN 131.)
mn132:11.1: “That’s how I was inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night.”
mn132:11.3: It’s good that you were inspiring the mendicants with a talk on the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night.”
mn132:13-19.1: And the Buddha repeated the verses and analysis once more.
mn132:13-19.17: That is what the Buddha said.
mn132:13-19.18: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
